Two ten-sided dice are rolled simultaneously, one representing the double digits of the roll, and the other representing the single digits. Ten-sided dice (single digits only) are rolled to determine other numerical outcomes, such as theÂ DurationÂ of an activated effect, the totalÂ DamageÂ inflicted by a source and others.Â When a roll of 10 occurs, the 10 counts towards the outcome of the roll; the die is then re-rolled, and the new outcome is added to the total.Â This process is repeated for each result of 10, any number of times, before the final sum of the roll can be determined. Whenever any numerical values need to be multiplied or divided, resulting in decimals, the result is always rounded up.

The Narrator may choose to impose a circumstantial Bonus or Penalty on any roll attempted, befitting the situation under which the action is attempted. A Bonus is applied on a favored roll, while a Penalty on a disfavored roll. Bonuses and Penalties apply to a singular roll, and after the roll is made all Bonuses and Penalties are removed.

A Bonus on a roll may range from +10% to +100%, and a Penalty on a roll may range from -10% to -100%. Bonuses above +50% are considered plot devising interventions, while Penalties below -50% are actions which go against all odds, doomed to fail on most occasions.

However, if a roll is affected by both a Bonus and a Penalty, subtract the latter from the former to determine the circumstantial modifier which will ultimately affect the roll. A Metanthropes Session consists of Scenes, where Protagonists and NPCs interact through dialogue and individual actions to shape the story. Such Scenes are not turn-based, and Characters can interact in real-time as actors in a play. However, whenever any number of Characters involved in a Scene want to perform opposing or contradicting actions, with different interests and conflicting purposes, then a turn-based Action Scene commences. During an Action Scene, in-game time comes to a halt, and Character actions become subject to a specific set of rules presented in this section.

Â 

Initiative

Â 

During an Action Scene, Characters act in Turns.Â  The order by which each Character may act is determined by an Initiative roll. Initiative is what sets the play order for all Characters involved in an Action Scene. When the Narrator calls for Initiative, all Characters involved in the Action Scene proceed to make a Reflexes roll. The Character with the most accumulated âœ”ï¸ will play first, followed by the one with the second most âœ”ï¸, up until the Character with the least âœ”ï¸ has played. Then the Character with the least âŒ will play, followed by the one with the second least âŒ, up until the Character with the most âŒ has played as well. In case of a Critical Success or a Critical Failure, the Character who made the roll is awarded a Destiny as usual during such rolls, and accumulates 10 *âœ”ï¸Â  in case of a Critical Success or 10 *Â âŒÂ  in case of a Critical Failure. There is no additional reward or punishment at Critical Rolls during Initiative.

Â 

In case multiple Characters enter the Initiative with the same outcome, who ever has the highest ReflexesÂ plays first, followed by the one with the second highest and so on. Â In case any Characters who have the same Initiative outcome, and both have the exact same number at their Stat who was involved at rolling Initiative: then both Characters receive a Destiny and make an additional Initiative roll between them to determine who goes first between them.Â Some Characters who might have Metapowers such as 6th Sense, might roll Initiative with a different Stat, other than Reflexes.

Characters C and D both had the same result, but Character D has a higher Reflexes score. The final order of play is the following: Character B, Character A, Character D, and Character C.Â

Turn

Â 

A Turn begins whenever it is a Characterâ€™s turn to play during an Action Scene. A Turnâ€™s duration in-game is usually a few seconds, unless the Narrator states otherwise.Â  Read below the segment â€œDuring my Turnâ€ for more about what can be accomplished during a Turn.

Â 

Round

Â 

When all Characters involved in the Action Scene completed their Turn, a RoundÂ is complete. A full Action Scene Round lasts up to thirty seconds, although the in-game time of each Round is largely dependent on the nature of the actions undertaken by the Characters and the situation in-game.

Â 

Cycle

Â 

A Cycle consists of two consecutive Rounds within an Action Scene. Following the end of the first Round, all Characters involved in the Action Scene play again, using the same Initiative score. After the second Round is completed, the first Cycle of the Action Scene ends. After each Cycle ends, each Character involved in the Action Scenes proceeds to make a subsequent Reflexes roll to determine the next Cycleâ€™s Initiative order. When the next Cycle is over, repeat the process until the Narrator declares the Action Scene is over.

Â 

It is possible for a Character to increase their position of the Initiative order of play during their Turn. That can be accomplished, for example, by increasing one's Reflexes score during their Turn, and bypassing this way the previous Character's total Initiative score. When that occurs, during the next Round of the same Cycle, that Character will increase their position to the Initiative order.

Â  Â 

During My Turn

Â 

During aÂ Turn, a Character can Roleplay,Â  perform a Movement (move my Character around, and interactÂ with the environment), and attempt Actions (anything which involves dice rolling). Roleplaying during my Turn during an Action Scene is different than Roleplaying during any other Scene; it should not be extensive or highly elaborate, as there is less time to engage in dialogue while performing other actions and moving around.Â Players are encouraged to allow for minimal â€œfree Roleplayâ€ during their Turns, limited to a few lines when it is my Turn, and only a couple outside of my Turn, within the Round. However, in the event I want my ProtagonistÂ to engage in more extensive Roleplay during my Scene, I can choose to forgo doing Actions, or Movement, or even my whole Turn, at the Narratorâ€™s discretion.

Â 

Wait

Â 

In the case a Character is not ready to play theirÂ Turn right away, but they do not want to lose their involvement in the Round, they can choose to Wait.
